thread.title: Fly beside birds at new family-friendly Wild Flight experience at Wild Life Sydney zoo in Darling Harbour
thread.title_full: Fly beside birds at new family-friendly Wild Flight experience at Wild Life Sydney zoo in Darling Harbour | Travel | Travel News and Holiday Deals | | The Advertiser

author: Angela Saurine Best Weekend
title: Fly beside birds at new family-friendly Wild Flight experience at Wild Life Sydney zoo in Darling Harbour
text:
RAINBOW lorikeets swoop beside me, screeching loudly, while zebra finches flutter their wings below my feet, which dangle over the kangaroo enclosure.
It’s a sunny blue-sky day, and I can see the water of Darling Harbour glistening in the distance as I pull myself along the rope towards the crocodile pen where somewhere below me 5m-long saltie Rex, one of the star attractions at Wild Life Sydney, is lurking.
The new Wild Flight experience is truly unique.
Before arriving I had envisaged flying through the air above the animals on a zip-line, but the new attraction turns out to be a much more serene activity.
Rainbow lorikeets love meeting humans at the new attraction. Picture: Supplied Source: Supplied
After climbing the stairs to the platform we are strapped into our seats and harnessed in. An eight-point safety check follows before we begin to pull ourselves around the 70m track inside the netted dome that is the zoo’s aviary.
We pass 8m above the first enclosure, where eastern grey kangaroos Martha and Daphne reside alongside four agile wallabies, before continuing to the crocodile enclosure, which we soar 12m above.
“It’s the only installation of its kind in the world because it’s something we designed specifically for this purpose,” Merlin Entertainments’ general manager of Darling Harbour attractions Steve Hinks says.
“It’s about putting guests in the environment of the animals and seeing the world from the perspective of our birdlife — a self-paced experience through the tree tops. Guests can interact with the birds in their environment and you’re looking at them at eye level while they’re flying.
Journalist Angela Saurine takes to the air. Photo: Bob Barker. Source: News Corp Australia
“Usually people see birds from the ground looking up or walking around on the ground but to be in the air watching them fly past is a really unique experience.”
While the attraction has been a hit with humans during the school holidays, Hinks says the birds also love it.
“They will quite often be found perching on the rails waiting for people to come along,” he says. “The lorikeets in particular are extremely inquisitive and they’re quite often holding on to the net talking to guests as they come through. It’s quite a lot of fun. I think the longer this is in place the more comfortable they will become.”
Children under 12 must be accompanied by an adult, with most people taking about 20 minutes to complete the activity.
Lauren Muddell, from West Ryde, and her 10-year-old daughter Mikayla were among the first to try the attraction.
“It’s fun,” Mikayla says. “We saw lots of birds — budgies, lorikeets and finches. We could hear them screeching a lot. We could see the crocodile enclosure and see out to the water. I’d give it a score of 10 out of 10.”
Follow Angela Saurine on Twitter: @angela_saurine
Wild Life Sydney, 1-5 Wheat Rd, Darling Harbour; entry adult $40, child 4-15 years $28, Wild Flight $15, 1800 206 158, wild-life.com.au
Rex the saltwater crocodile. Picture: John Appleyard Source: News Limited
Originally published as Fly alongside the birds at new Darling Harbour attraction
